summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from 2019 regarding travel approval requests for federal prosecutors and investigators to conduct victim interviews in Florida and Los Angeles as part of the Epstein investigation (United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618). It shows the logistical planning for the investigation's witness interviews.

connections.description: Work together as part of the investigative/prosecution team traveling to conduct victim interviews for the Epstein case.

events.title: Planned travel to Fort Lauderdale for victim interview
events.description: Travel approval was granted for investigators to fly to Fort Lauderdale to interview a recently identified victim. The trip was planned as a same-day round trip.

events.title: Planned travel to Los Angeles for victim interview
events.description: Travel approval was granted for a multi-day trip to Los Angeles to conduct a victim interview. The team planned to reserve a hotel conference room for the interview.

events.title: Planned travel to West Palm Beach for victim interviews
events.description: Travel approval was granted for approximately three days of meetings and victim interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida. The team planned to reserve a hotel conference room.

events.title: Planned travel to West Palm Beach for case meetings
events.description: Travel approval was granted for approximately three days of meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida, for the United States v. Epstein investigation.

events.title: Planned travel to Florida for meetings and interviews
events.description: Initial travel approval request for two days of meetings and interviews in West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale for the Epstein investigation.

keyFacts: The document references the federal criminal case 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity.
Multiple travel requests in 2019 show an active investigation phase with victim interviews being conducted in Florida and California.
The prosecution team planned to use hotel conference rooms for conducting victim interviews during their travels.
The correspondence indicates coordination between Assistant U.S. Attorney S and investigator/agent M as part of the investigative team.
Travel was approved through a formal internal process, showing the organized nature of the federal investigation into Epstein.
